message: otherwise the nano might start cannibalizing revenue
"In other words: they want to sell an iPhone for under $200 without a contract."
Just like the iPod Nano further skyrocketed sales of the iPod, this is a smart move to compete with the cheaper Android models available on all networks.
i predict apple will sell a billion of them in the developing world
also, i think it's highly plausible that apple will do this, once facetime gets higher adoption, so that they can still keep some high-value-add features for the existing iphone
Would be pretty crazy if true!
depends a lot on the features, the screen size might be a hindrance and $200 is still quite a lot as you can get an android for $140 with good features, obv china made but still good for the prize
well, if it were $200 with no contract, that would probably work out to free with one

yeah maybe, but if there target audience in the developing world, then it wouldnt work out cos there are no contract based services. Unless they choose to work something like that, in which case it would be feasible
The oscillation of Apple's product forms continues. Build small. Then Big. Then small. The take-away message is keep building and keep selling. Apple makes me frown.
Without cheaper data plans, $200 isn't much cheaper than $600. The vast majority of the cost of owning a smartphone is the data plan — $1500+ over two years.
@ericsilva It could happen, Virgin Mobile has an Android plan with 300min w/ Unlimited Text/Data for $25 no contract. Handset cost is $250.
